Chinese name: 
Dong Quai/ 当归 (Dang Gui) 

 Scientific name: 
Angelica sinensis

Uses: 

- Tonifies the blood. 

- Lubricates the intestines. 

- Relieve constipation. 

- Reduce Dysmenorrhea (menstrual cramps) and help with irregular menstruation.

Precautions: 

- Research suggests not to intake dong quai during pregnancy or breastfeeding as it could alter the activity of uterine contractions and may increase the risk of abortion. 

- Women with heavy bleeding, flu and abdominal bloating must not consume the herb. 

- There was report of a baby born with birth defects to a mother who took a product containing dong quai and other herbs during the first 3 months of pregnancy.

Chinese name: 
Xiao Hui Xiang/ 小茴香 

 Scientific name: 
Foeniculum vulgare

Uses: 

- Disperses cold. 

- Relieves pain. 

- Aids in digestion 

- Dietary nitrates present in fennel help lower blood pressure and protect the heart. 

- Selenium found in fennel appears to stimulate production of killer T-cells. This suggests that it can improve the immune response to infection. 

- Some practitioners believe it can be used to aid indigestion and increase the production of milk in nursing women

Precautions: 

- May cause uterine contractions, miscarriage or premature labour, as well as allergic reactions. 

- Fennel is a natural emmenagogue, which means it could trigger the menstrual cycle and lead to vaginal bleeding, ultimately causing miscarriage. 

- Consume in moderation, and avoid it altogether if your doctor advises against it.

Chinese name: 
Jin Zhan Ju/ 金盏菊 

 Scientific name: 
Calendula officinalis

Uses: 

- Increases blood flow to skin healing wounds and rashes. 

- Relieves blood stagnation. 

- Reduces inflammation/ Clears toxins. 

- Tonifies liver. 

- Helps with estrogen deficiency.

Precautions: 

- Its use during pregnancy could result in harm to your developing baby. 

- Since it is used to start menstruation, taking it internally during pregnancy could cause uterine stimulation, which may result in premature labor. 

- Avoid usage if you are breast-feeding.
